goal.en:
IMPORTANT: This course was specifically designed for 
our English graduate students. If you are NOT an English 
graduate student, you will not be able to enroll given the objectives of my course. 

This theory-based course concentrates on the notion of 
epistemic injustice which intersects conceptual matrices 
in epistemology, political and moral philosophy. 
Contemporary social epistemologists have turned their 
attention from ideal epistemic situations to quotidian 
contexts in which social identity and power play a 
significant role in the way we evaluate others’ statements and ours. Spaces of injustice where practical and 
theoretical knowledge is produced, disseminated, and 
assessed are not rare. This course seeks to provide 
students with philosophical tools to reflect on such 
spaces. To do so, we will examine two forms of epistemic injustice: testimonial and hermeneutical, both introduced by British philosopher Miranda Fricker in her 2007 
monograph Epistemic Injustice: Power and the Ethics of 
Knowing. We will pay attention to what is characteristic of 
them, cases illustrating them, and references preceding and following M. Fricker’s introduction of the terms.

outline.en:
ALL COURSE CONTENT WILL BE PROVIDED IN
ENGLISH.
All weekly sessions comprise (i) a lecturing part; and (ii) a
discussion section.
This three-part course is motivated by the following
questions:
Introduction: What is ‘epistemic injustice’ within the area
of social epistemology?
Section 1: What is testimonial injustice?
Section 2: What is hermeneutical injustice?

textbook.en:
A copy of the course material will be ready on February 
19. References include text, visual and audio material.
Some required and optional references could be modified in order to comply with course discussions.
Key course references: 

Berenstain, Nora, 2016, “Epistemic Exploitation” Ergo, an Open Access Journal of Philosophy 3. 

Dotson, Kristie, 2011, “Tracking Epistemic Violence, 
Tracking Practices of Silencing” Hypatia 26(2). 

Fricker, Miranda, 2009, Epistemic Injustice: Power and 
the Ethics of Knowing, Oxford University Press.

Fricker, Miranda, Peter J. Graham, David Henderson ＆ 
Nikolaj J.L.L. Pedersen (eds.), 2021, The Routledge 
Handbook of Social Epistemology, Routledge. 

Kidd, Ian James, José Medina, Gaile Pohlhaus Jr. (eds.), 2019, The Routledge Handbook of Epistemic Injustice, 
Routledge.
